p.s: This how-to instruction set will guide any student , either at the high school or undergraduate level , on reading Plato ’s Gorgias .
As a student of any level in English one will run into classical texts at some point .
Plato ’s Gorgias is a text that is relevant to the field of Rhetoric and Composition Studies , as it debated the uses and misuses of rhetoric as a verbal/written genre .
The following sections ( supplies , before you read , while you ’re reading , and after you read ) will slowly guide the reader of this how-to in understanding the text at hand .

item.s: Go to a workspace with all of the supplies .
This will limit the number of times you will have to stop reading the text .
The dialogue in the Gorgias is unfamiliar and therefore may require you to re-read and focus .
This is why having a workspace that is comfortable for you will help to limit frustration and distractions .
When choosing a workspace pick somewhere that you are able to study and focus .
This could be done in a library , home or coffee shop where ever is best for you .
Practice Active Reading Strategies .
Active reading is employing different methods to help understand a text before and while you read .
Using active reading methods before you begin reading will help to ease the frustration that can follow reading a difficult text .

Here are a few links for more information on pre-reading strategies
Study Guides and Strategies
7 Pre-Reading Strategies that Increase Comprehension

list.item:
Understand why the text is valuable for your field ( English , Rhetoric and Composition , Communications , Media studies , Philosophy ... ) .
Plato ’s Gorgias is important because it is a core text use to define the function of Rhetoric .
As a student studying in the field of English as a BA or an MA , this understanding is fundamental to how the genre is understood .
Many scholars use this text as a way to argue within their own works .
If you have a good base understanding of this text , you will be able to read others with less frustration .
Especially , if you are a student in the field of Rhetoric and Composition Studies as the piece helped to define the field in which you study .

Do background research into the Ancient Greek Scene .
This should be the history the scholar Plato and settings , themes , and characters of Gorgias to gain context via a quick online search .
This will help you to read the text easier because you will be familiar with this writing style , base themes and limit frustration at unfamiliar concepts and jargon .
For example , virtue and the functions of rhetoric are themes discussed within this text .

item.s: Write focus questions about why the concepts or ideas in this text matters .
This can be typically 3-4 questions bases on your research you have conducted on the text .
These will help you to center your reading of this text .
Some sample questions you may ask are :
What take does Plato have in terms of the use of rhetoric in society ?
What other characters are involved ?
Do they have the same viewpoints as Plato or are they different ?
How does Plato differ from the sophists ?
Does Plato 's position on rhetoric make sense in modern studies of rhetoric ?
Take notes in the margins .
They can come in the form of comments or questions , but actively engaging with the text allows you to retain what you are reading .
Mark any unfamiliar jargon while reading .
Look up unfamiliar jargon after reading the text completely as this will help to keep a focus on reading .
This will limit frustration because of unfamiliar words .

Some unfamiliar jargon that you may come across could include :
sophist
harangue
techne
oratory/orator
nomos
Mark any main themes around the function/defining of Rhetoric .
In this piece , Plato is discussing , through Socrates , the meaning , and uses of rhetoric .
Socrates is engaged in an argument with Gorgias who believed that rhetoric is the art of persuasion .
Gorgias is a sophist .
The sophists are teachers that instruct others to make a living , and not just for the pleasure of having knowledge .
The art of persuasion that Gorgias is speaking is used to make money and other reasons that Socrates deems immoral .
Therefore , Socrates deems rhetoric as a skill , unlike philosophy which is an art form .
This piece is one of the first known sightings of the word “ rhetoric ” and it gives an insight into the functions and uses of rhetoric as a genre .
Take notes on characters stances .
This piece is centered around a debate going on between Socrates and Gorgas about what function of rhetoric .
All characters involved have different stances on the definition of rhetoric .
This idea will inform your core understanding of the meaning of Plato ’s Gorgias .

The characters you will most likely come across are :
Socrates
Gorgias
Polus
Callicles
Chaerephon

list.item: Look up any jargon you did not understand .

item.s: Answer the focus questions that you wrote before reading .
Being able to answer these questions can assess how much is taken away from the work from the initial read .
Ask yourself how this text relates to the goals of the course you are currently enrolled in or how it relates to other texts you have read so far .
Assess your understanding of the text .
Did you understand the work ?
Remember that this text is not easy to understand and can be confusing for first time readers .
But , this is okay and expected , because reading as a process is not linear , but recursive .
Meaning that it may take more than one attempt to begin understanding a text .
Reread the text .
Take your time and read through the piece once more to help gain a better understanding of the material .
Read additional summaries .
If you are still having issues understanding this text go back and read a summary or book review .
Talk it over with others in your class .
Ask your teacher or professor some questions regarding the text to help gain some insight .
